items.title: History of the United States dollar - Wikipedia
items.htmlTitle: History of the United States dollar - Wikipedia
items.snippet:
The word dollar is derived from Low Saxon cognate of the High German Thaler. 
The most commonly circulated and readily available currency, used by common 
Americans, at this time, was the Spanish Peso, also known as the "Spanish 
milled dollar", which was valued for its high silver content. In the early 19th 
century, gold ...

items.title: United States dollar - Wikipedia
items.snippet:
In other words, this act designated the United States dollar as the unit of currency 
of the United States. Unlike the Spanish milled dollar, the U.S. dollar is based 
upon a decimal system of values. In addition to the dollar the coinage act officially 
established monetary units of mill or one-thousandth of a dollar (symbol ₥), cent
 ...

items.title: MYR | Malaysian Ringgit | OANDA
items.snippet:
Malaysia replaced the Spanish silver dollar with the Indian Rupee in 1837. After 
30 years ... Within the first 5 months, the Malaysian Dollar had decreased in value 
by 14.3%. ... The currency value fluctuated from 3.80 to 4.40 to the dollar before 
Bank Negara Malaysia pegged the Ringgit to the US Dollar in September 1998.
items.htmlSnippet:
Malaysia replaced the Spanish silver dollar with the Indian Rupee in 1837. After

Bank Negara Malaysia pegged the Ringgit to the US Dollar in September 1998.

items.title: Gold Standard History and Facts
items.snippet:
By 560 B.C., the Lydians had figured out how to separate the gold from the silver, 
and so created the first truly gold coin. ... That's why Spain, Portugal, and England 
sent Columbus and other explorers to the New World. ... As a result, most 
countries simply pegged the value of their currency to the dollar instead of to gold
.

.

metatags.og:title: When the Dollar Was Backed By Gold
metatags.og:description: Understand gold standard history, including when the U.S. went off the gold standard, and why. Here's why it's still an asset of real value.

intended to be a replacement for the London Gold Fix, the primary price-
discovery mechanism for gold bullion today. The London “bullion” market is not a 
market in bullion. Rather, it is a market in “unallocated” gold, defined [...]
